Comment: Hi all. Here is a game - my first on GameKnot's new Slow Ladder - in which, thanks mainly to some less-than-accurate opening play on the part of my opponent, I launched a successful minor piece attack early in the game. As per the Ladder challenge rules (challenger plays Black, defender plays White) I had the White pieces, and I open with my usual queen pawn.

This is a transposing move, often seen played by Black. It is very flexible: after 2.c4, Black can transpose into a Nimzo-Indian with 2...Nf6, a Queen's Gambit Declined with 2...d5, a Benoni with 2...c5, or even a Dutch Defence with 2...f5. The main drawback is that it fails to take a hold of the e4-square, so White is not prevented from placing two pawns in the centre.
Transposing back into a French Defence position. Black's most common move now is to follow up with the key French move 2...d5, striking back at White's centre.
Instead, Black strikes from the wing, assaulting White's d-pawn rather than the e-pawn. This may transpose back into a main line French Defence position though.

I am not entirely convinced by Black's opening play. This seems now to have transposed into a sort of Open Sicilian variation - not great for me, as I have no experience with Sicilian lines. However, Black has not yet exchanged pawns on d4. I feel that Black's play is too conservative here.

I am not entirely convinced by Black's opening play. This seems now to have transposed into a sort of Open Sicilian variation - not great for me, as I have no experience with Sicilian lines. However, Black has not yet exchanged pawns on d4. I feel that Black's play is too conservative here.

I stop Black from castling with this queen exchange, and take a lead in development. My light-squared bishop is now on a strong square, and cannot be chased away with ...d5 since Black's d-pawn no longer exists!

I stop Black from castling with this queen exchange, and take a lead in development. My light-squared bishop is now on a strong square, and cannot be chased away with ...d5 since Black's d-pawn no longer exists!

I stop Black from castling with this queen exchange, and take a lead in development. My light-squared bishop is now on a strong square, and cannot be chased away with ...d5 since Black's d-pawn no longer exists!

Developing a knight, but I cannot help but think that it would have been better-placed on c6. On d7. the knight controls less central space, and also blocks Black's light-squared bishop. I couldn't think why Black had not played 6...Nc6.
I continued with my plan - develop quickly, control powerful diagonals into Black's position (such as this f4-b8 diagonal) and build up a space advantage.

(?) I feel that Black should definitely be developing here; I can see no possible benefits of 7...a5. Perhaps ...a6 followed by ...b5 and a queenside expansion with tempo, but then only when Black is more developed.
Black hands me the weak b5-square on a silver platter. Time to place a very powerful outpost on it. I think that you can already see my attack forming.
Black hands me the weak b5-square on a silver platter. Time to place a very powerful outpost on it. I think that you can already see my attack forming.
If Black challenges my outpost with 9...Ba6, my knight is waiting to take up the reins - no pun intended - of the b5-outpost. Black decides not to...
...and moves an already developed piece again. Surely 9...Ngf6 would have been much, much better! I think Black needs to develop his understanding of opening principles here.
Leaping into the attack. 10...Ke7 is Black's only way of preventing a knight fork on f7, winning the exchange (I had no high hopes of my knight escaping).
Bringing a rook in to help with the attack, and hold Black's king down. 11.Rd1 also works.
Bringing a rook in to help with the attack, and hold Black's king down. 11.Rd1 also works.
Allowing an easy fork on c6, winning the rook.
I had been hoping for 13...Ke7 14.Nxc8#. Never mind, I still have a clear win.
I had been hoping for 13...Ke7 14.Nxc8#. Never mind, I still have a clear win.
I had been hoping for 13...Ke7 14.Nxc8#. Never mind, I still have a clear win.
I had been hoping for 13...Ke7 14.Nxc8#. Never mind, I still have a clear win.
Black's final, and still incomprehensible, error. Why doesn't he just recapture with the knight? Never mind...
Black's final, and still incomprehensible, error. Why doesn't he just recapture with the knight? Never mind...

A neat denouement to my winning minor piece attack. I can feel quite proud of myself for this win...however, I still remind myself that it was more my opponent who lost, than me who won. I would be interested to see viewers' comments!
